questions.question: If you double the normal force pressing two sliding surfaces together, the kinetic friction force will:
A wider tire on a car (assuming same material and load) provides:
options: Significantly more friction than a narrow tire.
Significantly less friction than a narrow tire.
questions.explanation: Friction depends on normal force and coefficient, not contact area (for most materials).

questions.question: To keep an object moving at a constant velocity across a rough floor, the applied force must:
options: Be greater than the maximum static friction.
Be exactly equal to the kinetic friction.
Be greater than the weight of the object.
questions.explanation: Constant velocity → equilibrium → net force = 0 → $F_{app} = f_k$.

questions.question: A block is on an incline. If the component of weight acting down the incline is $20\text{ N}$ and the maximum static friction is $25\text{ N}$, what happens?
options: The block moves up the incline.
questions.explanation: Down force $20\text{ N}$ is less than max static friction $25\text{ N}$, so block remains at rest.

questions.question: When a car accelerates forward without its tires slipping, the static friction from the road acts:
questions.explanation: Tires push backward on road; road pushes forward on tires (static friction) to accelerate car.

questions.question: The maximum static friction is given by:
Kinetic friction magnitude is:
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction is constant for given surfaces and normal force: $f_k = \mu_k F_N$.

questions.question: Typically, for the same surfaces:
questions.explanation: Static friction is generally harder to overcome, so $\mu_s > \mu_k$ for most materials.

questions.question: A $10\text{ kg}$ block is acted upon by a $25\text{ N}$ force directed East and a $15\text{ N}$ force directed West. What is the acceleration of the block?
A $10\text{ kg}$ crate is being pushed across a floor at a constant velocity of $2\text{ m/s}$. If the kinetic friction force is $30\text{ N}$, what is the magnitude of the applied force?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity → equilibrium → net force = 0 → $F_{app} = f_k = 30\text{ N}$.
